did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: Ferdinand Praeger Collection of Scores, circa 1829-1891
did.langmaterial: Collection material in English. Also includes song settings in French and German.

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library

did.abstract: This is the largest collection of Ferdinand Praeger's manuscripts in the world, consisting of approximately 480 works. The majority of the works are for piano, but the collection also includes chamber music for strings, large ensemble works, vocal works, and sketches. The dated works range from 1829-1891, but many works are undated.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Specified item], Ferdinand Praeger Collection of Scores, circa 1829-1891, Music Library, The State University of New York at Buffalo.

accessrestrict.head: Terms of Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials can be examined by qualified researchers in the Music Library during hours of operation during which Music Librarians are present. In order to insure access, researchers are advised to contact the Music Library in advance of visits.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: All material in the collection is in public domain.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Purchased in London by James Coover, Summer 1984.

accruals.head: Accruals and Additions
accruals.p: No further accruals are expected to this collection.

altformavail.head: Alternate Forms
altformavail.p: Selected scores and documents in the collection have been digitized. Links to digital copies are provided in the container list.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ferdinand Praeger was born in Leipzig on January 22, 1815, to a Dutch father and an English mother. As a child, he studied cello, piano, and violin. His father, Heinrich Aloys Praeger (1783-1854) worked as a musician, composer, and conductor. From 1815-1821, he conducted a small traveling opera company called the Joseph Seconda German Opera Company.

In 1831, at the age of 16, Praeger became a music teacher at The Hague and continued to study piano, violin, and composition. He moved to London in 1834, working as a teacher and traveling to give piano recitals, many of which included his own works. Praeger became the London correspondent for Robert Schumann's music journal, Neue Zeitschrift für Musik, in 1842. His contributions included highlights of London musical events, reviews of performances, and general discussions about current musical topics. Praeger held this position until 1890, the year before his death.

Praeger's compositions were performed in cities across Europe, including Paris, Leipzig, Berlin, Hamburg, and Meiningen. In London, his orchestral works were performed in private home concerts as well as larger venues, such as the Crystal Palace. On July 10, 1879, Praeger's students organized and presented a concert of his compositions in his honor.

Praeger is perhaps best known today for his connection with Richard Wagner. Wagner stayed with Praeger during a trip to London and the two apparently remained close friends. Following Wagner's death, Praeger wrote the book Wagner, as I Knew Him, which quickly became controversial and was pulled from publication. Wagner followers disputed the book, claiming that Praeger exaggerated his role in Wagner's life and portrayed Wagner in a negative way. Praeger's other literary contributions include the unpublished textbook, Guide Pratique pour la Composition avec des Illustrations Originales, and a translation of Emil Naumann's Illustrated History of Music from 1886.

Little is known about Praeger's family. He married a French woman named Leonie around 1850. His first son, Henry, was born a year later. In 1855, they had another son named Richard Wagner Praeger, to whom Richard Wagner was godfather; but he is not known to have lived to adulthood.
Ferdinand Praeger died on September 2, 1891, in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 484 items, all but a few of which are manuscript scores. The majority of the works are for piano, but the collection also includes chamber music for strings, large ensemble works, vocal works, and sketches. The dated works range from 1829-1891, but many works are undated. A small number of documents are also included in the collection. This is the largest collection of Praeger's musical manuscripts in the world, and these works have not been included in any previous writings or works lists related to Praeger. Nearly all the scores are in Praeger's own hand.

The manuscripts are in varying conditions. Some are in very good condition, considering their age, while others are close to disintegration. Some pieces have become stuck together, and in some cases, only bits of one page are stuck to another, obscuring the music. These pieces have been scanned digitally to create a composite image of the full page wherever possible, however, some information is inevitably lost.

Praeger used paper inserts to correct or alter his manuscripts. These are small pieces of paper glued over the original passage to replace it with different music. Over time, many of these inserts have become loose or detached from the manuscripts. Effort was made to match the loose inserts to their original places and mark them with measure numbers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in seven series:

scopecontent.p: Some of the piano sonatas indicate a key area, but not the mode. These works begin in the minor mode and end in the major mode of that key.

Contents: 128 : Andante religioso -- 129 : Allegro Maestoso -- 130 : [no marking].

It is unclear why some of these works were identified as piano scores of works for a larger ensemble, and how it was determined whether this ensemble was an orchestra or a wind band. Only some of the pieces in this category have specific markings that indicate that they were intended for a larger ensemble. Some have notes that state that they were to be scored for orchestra, wind instruments, or strings, while others only have instrument names noted above the staff at a few points in the score. Many have no markings at all, so we cannot be certain that they are indeed piano scores of larger works.

unittitle.title: [Song cycle for medium voice and piano] /

scopecontent.p: For medium voice and piano. Texts not present. Title supplied by cataloger. Holograph (Ink). Songs 1-10 were received in the same folder. Song 11 was originally listed as a violin and piano work in the Finkelman inventory and song 12 (War song) was received in a separate folder, but both appear to belong to this set.

Contents: Ballad song (Very moderate) [G major] -- Song (Slowly) [G major] -- Song (Very slowly, dreamily) [A♭ major] -- Song (Moderate time) [E♭ major] -- Ballad (Allegretto) [G major] -- Song (Very slowly) [E♭ major] -- Ballad (Moderate) [F major] -- Song (Lively with emotion) [E♭ major] -- Ballad (With spirit) [G major] -- Song (Slowly, gracefully) [F major] -- War song or military ditty (Moderato) [F major].

Contents: Chor (Maestoso) -- Chor (Allegro moderato) -- Lieges marsch -- Hymnus -- Lied -- Romance -- March & chorus -- March -- Lied (Molto moderato).
This series contains two sketchbooks and other miscellaneous sketches and fragments. These items were placed in folders in the groupings in which they were received.

Contents: Ballade sentimentale -- Ballad [in E♭ major] -- Elegy -- Air nationale -- Choral -- String quartet -- Ballad -- Trio for strings [in] E minor -- Valse sentimentale -- Etude de tristesse -- Scherzo -- Cavatina.
Sketches for various instrumentations. Cover title. Holograph (Ink) ; some sketches in pencil. Corrections on inserts pasted throughout.
Contents: Piano concerto -- Savoyardenlied -- Sonata 8 -- Klavier Konzert -- Quartett in G -- 6th sonata in E-flat -- Nocturne-adagio -- Introduction -- Piano trio or concerto.

Sketches for various and unknown instrumentations. Placed in folders in groupings as received. Title supplied by cataloger. Holograph (Ink) ; some sketches in pencil. Some sketches have corrections on inserts pasted throughout. Dated sketches range from 1842-1889; many sketches are undated.

Contents: [1]. Andante (1 leaf) -- [2]. Caption: Re-engrave from A to B (final page numbered 13) -- [3]. Allegro moderato (1 leaf; colophon: 86 bars) -- [4]. Moderato, continued by Poco meno mosso (2 pages) -- [5]. No. 3, No. 4, No. 5, No. 6 (4 pages) -- [6]. Ben pronunziato la melodia (2 leaves) -- [7]. Allegro molto, 10 April 89 (1 leaf) -- [8]. Für Violins, 10 Decr. 1844 (4 pages) -- [9]. Sonata in G [for] violin and piano: Scherzo (2 leaves) -- [10]. Untitled work with solo line above grand staff in 9/8 meter (2 pages) -- [11]. Album leaf : Quartett : Fairy scherzo, 23 Aug. 87 (1 oblong leaf) -- [12]. Pages 25-29 of untitled orchestral work (5 oblong pages) -- [13]. Andantino for two violins, viola, violoncello, and contrabass (1 leaf) -- [14]. Three untitled leaves: two pencil manuscripts and one ink oblong -- [15]. Untitled ink manuscript on grand staff (2 pages) -- [16]. Untitled pieces 1: Andante (5 March 1842), 2: Vivace, 3: Cantabile (11 March 1842), 4 (30 July 1842) (4 pages) -- [17]. 1 folder of loose fragments, including a manuscript with figured bass markings.
This series contains a small number of non-musical documents related to Praeger.

unittitle.title: Agreement with the Earl of Dysart /

scopecontent.p: Specifies that Praeger is to send compositions to the Earl of Dysart quarterly for 12 years, beginning on Mar. 1, 1890. Signed by J.A. Bertram, Esq.

unittitle.title: Folder for delivery of compositions to the Earl of Dysart /

scopecontent.p: Front of folder: 2d Grand Symphonic Poem in F for full orchestra. Received housing Legend for winds. Specifies two dates of delivery in accordance with the agreement with the Earl of Dysart. Signed by B.L. Mosely, Ferdinand Praeger, H.J. Edwards, and Lilian Grace Mary Blyth.
Each folder reads: Eight "Fleeting Thoughts" by Ferdinand Praeger. Each folder was received housing eight of the Fleeting thoughts piano pieces. The dates of these pieces range from 1882-1885.
4 copies, reading: Mr. Ferdinand Praeger, Lansdowne, 23 Brackenbury Road, Shepherds Bush, W. One has note: Same house as 4 Bradmore Park Terrace.

otherfindaid.head: Additional Guides
otherfindaid.p: All scores in the collection are cataloged in WorldCat and are available in BISON, the online catalog for the University at Buffalo Libraries, by performing a "Title begins with" search under "Ferdinand Praeger Collection of Scores".

The previous inventory of the collection, compiled by M. Finkelman in 1985, may be found in the Music Library collection with the call number ML 410 P789 AXF5. This inventory lists the items in a different order than the current arrangement and does not include all items in the collection. It can also be seen online.

relatedmaterial.head: Other collections of Ferdinand Praeger's Manuscripts

defitem.item: Northwestern University holds manuscripts of both musical and literary works by Ferdinand Praeger. Their holdings can be viewed by clicking the link above and performing a "Title" search for "Praeger, Ferdinand".

The British Library holds approximately 93 manuscripts of Praeger's works, most of which are for piano. Their holdings can be viewed by accessing their main catalog through the link above and searching for "Praeger, Ferdinand".
